pages:
Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 46194  
Regional–Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
Statistical Capacity Development  
for Social Inclusion and Gender Equality
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  CRVS  –  civil registration and vital statistics 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  EDGE  –  Evidence and Data for Gender Equality 
  ESCAP  –  Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific 
  MDG  –  Millennium Development Goal 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
  UN    –  United Nations  
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional–Capacity development technical assistance (R-CDTA) 
Targeting  –  General intervention 
classification 
Sector (subsector)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Capacity development (institutional development; client 
relations, network, and partnership development), regional 
cooperation and integration (other regional public goods), gender 
equity (gender equity in empowerment and rights)  
Location (impact)  –  Regional (high), national (high), urban (medium), rural (medium) 
Partnerships  –  UN Statistics Division, UN Entity for Gender Equality and the 
Empowerment of Women, UN Economic and Social Commission 
for Asia and the Pacific, World Health Organization, Health 
Metrics Network, and other development partners 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
Vice-President  B. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
Assistant Chief   
Economist  D. Brooks, Development Indicators and Policy Research Division, ERD 
   
Team leader  K. Joshi, Senior Statistician, ERD 
Team members  C. Palanyandy, Lead Statistician, ERD 
M. Pascua, Associate Economics and Statistics Officer, ERD 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Timely  and  reliable  sex-disaggregated  data  on  education,  health  and  demography 
(through civil registration and vital statistics [CRVS] systems), employment, and on emerging 
areas of asset ownership and entrepreneurship are needed to monitor progress in achieving 
inclusive  growth  (through  socially  inclusive  policies  and  equality  of  opportunity)  and 
development goals such as the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). Coordinated initiatives 
by development partners have sought to build country capacity to collect such data. A new 
global initiative on gender statistics—Evidence and Data for Gender Equality (EDGE)—is led by 
the United Nations (UN) Statistics Division and the UN Entity for Gender Equality and the 
Empowerment of Women in collaboration with other development partners, and seeks to make 
available gender indicators on health, education, employment, entrepreneurship, and  asset 
ownership.1  The Statistics Division of the UN Economic and Social Commission for Asia and 
the  Pacific  (ESCAP)  is  leading  an  initiative  to  develop  a  regional  strategic  program  for 
improvement of CRVS systems in collaboration with development partners such as the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), Health Metrics Network, Plan International, Secretariat of the Pacific 
Community, UN Population Fund, UN Children’s Fund, World Health Organization, and others.  
2.  ADB  has  been  collaborating  with  development  partners  in  supporting  capacity 
development in Asia and the Pacific in the above areas. In planning this technical assistance 
(TA),2 partner agencies and statisticians from national statistical offices in Cambodia, Georgia, 
and the Philippines were consulted. This TA is designed to strengthen the capacity of selected 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  in  producing  gender  statistics  and  improving  CRVS 
systems. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The 4th High Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness recognized the critical need for a global 
action plan to enhance statistics capacity.3 It specifically highlighted the role of gender equality 
and women’s empowerment in achieving development results and the need to accelerate and 
deepen efforts to collect, disseminate, harmonize, and make full use of gender statistics to 
inform policy decisions. In 1995, the UN Beijing Platform for Action provided recommendations 
to regularly collect sex-disaggregated statistics, but major gaps in the availability and quality of 
gender statistics remain in many areas.4 There are standard definitions and methods of data 
collection  in  the  areas  of  education,  health  and  employment,  but  no  clear  standards  and 
commonly accepted definitions to guide data collection on entrepreneurship and ownership of 
assets  and  their  gender  dimensions.  Data  collected  through  country  surveys  may  not  be 
comparable because of a lack of commonly accepted definitions.5 There is a need for common 
                                                
1  The 3-year EDGE project receives funding from various development partners and will be implemented in 
partnership with UN regional commissions and development banks. It also addresses part of the Busan Joint 
Action Plan on Gender Equality and Development and builds on the work of the UN Inter-Agency and Expert Group 
on Gender Statistics to define a harmonized list of gender equality indicators based on the recommendations of the 
UN Statistical Commission, to serve as the basic framework for compiling statistics on women and men.  
2   The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section website on 24 October 2012. 
3   Para 18 c) of the Busan partnership document (available at www.busanhlf4.org) refers to partners’ commitment to 
A Busan Action Plan for Statistics (BAPS) (http://www.paris21.org/busan-action-plan) that sets out the renewed 
partnership to improve statistics in support of development effectiveness and results, and identifies emerging 
statistical programs, priorities and actions. Mainstreaming gender statistics and addressing weaknesses in the 
CRVS systems are included under the plan’s action 1 and are included among emerging priorities and programs. 
4   http://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/beijing/pdf/BDPfA%20E.pdf 
5  See, for instance, United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. 2010. Developing Gender Statistics: A 
Practical Tool. Geneva.

2 
 
standards for the collection of comparable data, and to understand problems faced by women 
entrepreneurs  and  their  roles  as  contributors  to  employment,  productivity,  innovation,  and 
economic growth. Surveys often collect household-level data on assets (real and financial), but 
understanding its gender dimensions requires additional information (e.g., whether assets are 
owned individually or jointly, how assets were acquired, the value and use of assets, who 
makes decisions regarding their economic use, and who derives income from assets).  
 
4.  The global  EDGE  project  aims  to (i)  develop  standard methods  and definitions for 
collecting sex-disaggregated data on entrepreneurship and ownership of assets, (ii) conduct 
pilot surveys for data collection in selected countries, and (iii) present standards to the UN 
Statistical Commission. The EDGE project will use a practical, cost-effective and sustainable 
data collection method, and make use of existing surveys (such as household surveys on living 
standards, income and expenditure; labor force surveys; and enterprise surveys) by including 
additional questions to elicit sex-disaggregated information.  
 
5.  CRVS systems are  the most comprehensive source of sex-disaggregated data on vital 
events at national and sub-national levels that can provide timely indicators of fertility, mortality 
(including maternal and child mortality for MDGs 4 and 5), and cause of death, which are very 
critical for social policy formulation and MDG monitoring. However, recent assessments6 show 
that these systems are suffering from incomplete registration and poor quality of vital statistics, 
leading to the use of costly donor-funded (and therefore unsustainable) household surveys. TA 7 
provided by ADB to support achievement of the MDGs in Asia and the Pacific indicated the 
need to develop reliable alternative sources of data for monitoring MDG progress, in particular, 
MDGs 4 and 5, while ADB TA8 on improving data sources for MDG monitoring  assessed 
weaknesses in the CRVS systems. The poor functioning of CRVS systems commonly stems 
from lack of awareness and political commitment, limited human and financial capacity, lack of 
incentive to register, barriers to registration (e.g., costs, distance from registration centers, and 
cultural norms), absence of adequate legal provisions, and lack of appreciation for timely and 
reliable statistics. Most countries lack good quality cause-of-death statistics, which is a serious 
impediment  to  a gender-based  approach  to  health  policy.  The  absence  of  well-functioning 
CRVS  systems  also  deprives  citizens  of  basic  legal  documents  such  as  birth,  death,  and 
marriage certificates, thereby denying basic rights and governance benefits to much of the 
population, especially the poor and marginalized people.  
 
6.  Improving CRVS systems requires a coordinated, long-term approach involving multiple 
stakeholders at the country and regional levels. Initial steps are now being taken by African 
states to improve their CRVS systems. This is reflected in the Africa Programme on Accelerated 
Improvement  of  Civil  Registration  and  Vital  Statistics.  In  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  ESCAP,  in 
coordination with development partners and member countries, has begun work on a regional 
strategic program for improvement of CRVS systems, and countries are being encouraged to 
undertake comprehensive assessments of their CRVS systems and develop prioritized strategic 
action plans. Initial regional activities (organizing a regional forum of experts, training programs, 
and country assessments organized by ESCAP) were supported under the ADB TA (footnote 7).  
                                                
6  As of September 2012, an ESCAP rapid assessment of the CRVS systems of 35 countries in Asia and the Pacific 
indicates 13 countries have weak or dysfunctional systems, 11 have systems that are functional but inadequate in 
many respects, while 11 have satisfactory systems that register more than 90% of births and deaths, but for which 
further improvements (e.g., in data quality and cause of death reporting) would be desirable.  
7   ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Supporting the Achievement of the Millennium Development Goals in the 
Asia and Pacific Region (Phase III). Manila (TA 6429-REG). 
8  ADB. 2006. Administrative Data Sources for the Monitoring of the Millennium Development Goal Indicators. Manila 
(TA 6356-REG).

3 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be improvement in the capacity of participating DMCs to 
produce  reliable  sex-disaggregated  statistics  on  ownership  of  assets  and  entrepreneurship 
using standard methods, and improvement in vital statistics from CRVS systems. The outcome 
of the TA will be improved methods to collect sex-disaggregated data on entrepreneurship and 
asset ownership, and improved CRVS systems in prioritized areas.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  To achieve the outcomes, the TA’s components will focus on (i) sex-disaggregated data 
on asset ownership and entrepreneurship, and (ii) improving CRVS systems.  
 
9.  Component  1:  Sex-disaggregated  data  on  assets  and  entrepreneurship.  This 
component will be implemented in close collaboration with development partners in the global 
EDGE initiative. The main outputs are (i) development of standard methods for collection of 
comparable  data  on  entrepreneurship  and  asset  ownership  by  gender,  and  preparation  of 
technical reports and inputs relating to global standards; (ii) training of DMC staff on new 
methods  of  collection  of  sex-disaggregated  data  on  entrepreneurship and  asset  ownership 
through regional and in-country trainings and workshops; and (iii) conduct of pilot data collection 
(surveys) in three selected DMCs using standard data collection methods for entrepreneurship 
and asset ownership. Limited funds and technical advice will be provided to participating DMCs 
to cover the cost of data collection for additional questions to be canvassed in the pilot surveys, 
data processing, data analysis, data review and validation, and preparation of country reports.  
 
10.  Based on preliminary discussions, Georgia, Mongolia, and the Philippines have been 
tentatively identified by ADB to participate in component 1 and to undertake the pilot surveys. 
The national statistics offices in each country will be the main counterpart government agency. 
The participation of countries will be determined (i) by their willingness to be involved in and 
commit to the project, (ii) through a review of the surveys they have planned during the project 
period,9 and (iii) through a review of existing survey questionnaires and their suitability for pilot 
surveys. Review process may include other countries if any of those in the tentative list could 
not meet all the criteria. The final selection of three DMCs will be made in consultation with the 
EDGE project to ensure a reasonable representation of countries from Asia and the Pacific.  
 
11.  Component 2: Improvements in civil registration and vital statistics. The CRVS 
component will be implemented in collaboration with ESCAP and other development partners 
supporting the regional strategic plan for improvement of CRVS systems in Asia and the Pacific. 
The  key  outputs  are  (i)  contribution  to  the  development  of  a  regional  strategic  plan  for 
improvement  of  CRVS  systems  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific,  which  is  a  collaborative  regional 
initiative  undertaken  by  development  partners  and  countries—to  be  collaborated  with  UN 
ESCAP to provide technical support and joint organization of workshops and conferences for 
advocacy and capacity building; (ii) approved country proposals for improving CRVS systems 
implemented for the three participating DMCs, which will be achieved by providing financial and 
technical support to selected DMCs to implement improvements in their CRVS systems in line 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
with the regional strategic plan and identified country priorities based on a comprehensive 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
                                                
9 Candidate surveys are household surveys on living standards, income and expenditures; labor force surveys; and 
enterprise surveys.

4 
 
assessment  of  CRVS  systems;10 and  (iii)  design  or  implementation  of  associated  training 
programs for improvement of CRVS systems in participating DMCs. DMC proposals will be 
reviewed  in  consultation  with  the  development  partners  supporting  CRVS  systems  at  the 
country level (such as the World Health Organization). The TA will also support collaboration 
with other developing regions and regional development banks to promote cooperation between 
developing countries and sharing of lessons and good practices. A consolidated report on the 
CRVS component will be prepared and widely distributed.  
 
12.  Three DMCs will participate under the CRVS component. Cambodia, Sri Lanka, and 
Timor-Leste have been tentatively identified based on comprehensive assessments of their 
CRVS systems and priority-setting for improving CRVS systems. The final selection will be 
guided by willingness of countries to participate and commit to the project, a review of country 
proposals based on comprehensive CRVS assessment reports and identified priorities, and 
consultations with other development partners. The counterpart agency, which will act as the 
focal agency in each DMC, could be each country’s national statistics office, civil registrar’s 
office, or ministry of health. 
 
13.  The success of the TA will require good coordination among development partners and 
ownership and commitment by participating DMCs in implementing project activities.  Multi-
sector coordination is particularly important for the CRVS systems. The availability of qualified 
experts and consultants to provide technical support is assumed; risks include a lack of capable 
counterpart support from participating DMCs, staff turnover, and changes in the country teams.  
   
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The costs will cover consultancy services 
for methodological work and technical advice to the countries, financial support to implement 
country-level  activities  such  as  surveys  and  data  collection,  CRVS  systems  development, 
training  and  workshops,  publications,  dissemination,  regional-level  events,  and  cooperation 
between developing countries. No activities will be undertaken in any participating DMC until the 
requisite no-objection has been obtained from the DMC. The detailed cost estimates are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB will be the executing agency. The TA will be administered by the ADB Economics 
and Research Department. Both components will be implemented over 36 months (December 
2012–November  2015)  in  collaboration  with  participating  DMCs. 11  Collaboration  with 
development  partners  will  align  activities  with  the  global  and  regional  initiatives,  avoid 
duplication of effort, and leverage development partner strengths. Partnership agreements will 
be made to coordinate technical activities during TA implementation. ADB will be represented in 
the steering committee and the technical working group of the global EDGE initiative, and in the 
                                                
10 Under the regional initiative, some countries have conducted comprehensive assessments of their CRVS systems, 
while assessments are in progress in others. The TA could support (i) development of strategic action plans 
including cost estimates to establish functional CRVS systems; (ii) improving coordination mechanisms for CRVS; 
(iii) improving registration  and sex-disaggregated statistics relating to births, deaths, and causes of death; (iv) 
improving methods of obtaining data on non-institutional deaths, developing innovative methods for registration 
management, and processing and compilation of vital statistics; and (v) development of staff capacity. 
11  This will coincide with the global EDGE project, which is slated to close by December 2015.

5 
 
regional committees for drafting the regional strategic plan for coordination of CRVS activities in 
Asia and the Pacific.  
 
16.  A memorandum of agreement with a comprehensive schedule of activities will be signed 
with  each  participating  DMC  to  implement  pilot  surveys  under  component  1,  or  CRVS 
improvement activities for DMCs participating in component 2. The agreements will specify an 
appropriate financial management facility. Funds for country-level activities will be disbursed in 
accordance  with  the  procedures  of  ADB's  advance  payment  facility.  The  financial  support 
provided to individual DMC’s will vary depending on the sample size and work associated with 
canvassing additional questions (component 1); and on country-specific prioritized activities for 
CRVS improvements (component 2).  
 
17.   The TA will be implemented by international, national, and administrative staff from 
ADB’s Development Indicators and Policy Research Division with support from international and 
national consultants. The division will collaborate with development partners engaged in the 
global EDGE initiative and regional CRVS initiatives, ADB regional departments12  engaged in 
related activities, and the Regional and Sustainable Development Department. Component 1 
will require an estimated 5 person-months of international and 15 person-months of national 
consultant inputs (average of 5 national person-months per DMC). Component 2 will require 3 
person-months of international and 12 person-months of national consultant inputs (average of 
4 national person-months per DMC). The national consultant inputs may vary depending upon 
country  needs. The remaining  27  person-months  of  national  consultant  inputs  will  support 
project  management,  research,  website  management,  and  data  processing  at  ADB 
headquarters. Collaborations with development partners and specialized institutions (e.g., the 
Statistical Institute for Asia and the Pacific and the University of Queensland Health Information 
System Knowledge Hub) will be established in the course of TA implementation and individual 
resource  persons  will  be  engaged  from  them  to  source  expertise  for  training,  facilitating 
workshops, and providing need-based technical support. Assignment per resource person will 
not exceed 10 working days.  
 
18.   The outline and specific terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The 
consultants will be hired as individuals and will be engaged directly by ADB in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Individual 
consultants are preferred over a firm in consideration of the limited and specialized technical 
services  required  for  implementing  the  TA  components.  Disbursements  will  be  made  in 
accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time  to time). The  procurement  of  any  equipment  will  be  done  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Proper turnover of equipment to 
the participating DMCs will be ensured upon project completion. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,100,000 on a grant basis 
for Statistical Capacity Development for Social Inclusion and Gender Equality, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.   
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
                                                
12  For example, with statistics capacity building activities of the Pacific Department and the Central and West Asia 
Department.

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consultants for Sex-Disaggregated Data on Assets and Entrepreneurship 
Component 
1.  International  gender  consultant  (5  person-months,  intermittent).  The  international 
consultant should have a strong background in (i) designing and evaluating sample surveys with 
national coverage; (ii) working with household and establishment surveys, and in mainstreaming 
gender into data collection processes, methods, and survey instruments; (iii) development of 
training  materials;  and  (iv)  capacity  development  of  developing  country  national  statistical 
systems (especially in Asia and the Pacific). Under the supervision of the ADB project officer, 
the consultant will work closely with the technical team at the global level (at the United Nations 
Statistics Division) and with the national consultants and the country teams in the project. The 
consultant will: 
(i)  identify suitable indicators; review existing national statistical surveys (including 
administrative  data  sources),  methodologies,  data  collection  instruments, 
definitions, and classification systems used for existing indicators associated with 
entrepreneurship and ownership of assets; undertake related literature review to 
mainstream gender in statistical collections on these areas; 
(ii)  document how to mainstream gender in national statistical surveys and at strategic 
data collection entry points to collect data on entrepreneurship and ownership of 
assets; and develop standards, definitions, and guidelines for collecting data in 
these areas; 
(iii)  prepare  two  technical  papers  on  asset  ownership  and  entrepreneurship, 
respectively, and a preliminary (interim) technical report on the standards and 
methods based on the above review; 
(iv)  in collaboration with the country teams, design a pilot data collection methodology; 
identify  appropriate  new  questions  for  survey  instruments  and  data  collection; 
prepare field operations instruction manuals and data quality control; train trainers 
and enumerators; analyze and tabulate data; and prepare reports and disseminate 
results on entrepreneurship and asset ownership; 
(v)  prepare country reports with gender analysis of assets and entrepreneurship with 
lessons from pilot exercises; 
(vi)  prepare a consolidated technical report on the pilot surveys, definitions, gender-
related questions, classifications, and methods for collection of gender statistics on 
entrepreneurship and ownership of assets, to feed into the technical report on 
international standards to be developed under the global EDGE initiative;  
(vii)  assist the project officer in preparing technical documents and presentations for the 
workshops and meetings; 
(viii)  assist the project officer in organizing country and regional workshops, prepare the 
agenda and technical documents for the workshop, act as a resource person as 
needed, prepare workshop reports, follow-up identified actions, and administer the 
costs of organizing workshops where needed; and 
(ix)  perform other related tasks as may be assigned. 
2.  National  gender  consultant  (15  person-months,  intermittent;  5  person-months  per 
country). The national consultant should have experience with sample surveys of households 
and establishments conducted by national statistical systems (including knowledge regarding 
sample estimation and questionnaire design, and working with survey data) and their use in 
analyzing gender issues in the country. The national gender consultant in each participating

Appendix 3  11 
country will assist the international gender consultant in implementing the project activities and 
work with the country team. The consultant will: 
(i)  provide  research  assistance  to  the  international  consultant  in  mainstreaming 
gender into the national statistical surveys and at strategic entry points of data 
collection, particularly relating to entrepreneurship and ownership of assets in their 
country;  
(ii)  work closely with country team under the guidance of the international consultant, 
and  collect  documents  and  provide  inputs  for  the  review  of  existing  surveys 
(including  administrative  data  sources),  methodologies,  questionnaires, 
classification  systems  used  for  existing  indicators,  and  definitions  and  data 
collection methods relating to entrepreneurship and ownership of assets from the 
perspective of mainstreaming gender in the country’s statistical collections; 
(iii)  provide assistance relating to the design of pilot surveys at the country level, 
implementation  of  data  collection  and  analysis,  and  in  the  preparation  and 
dissemination of the draft country report;  
(iv)  organize country workshops and/or training programs, prepare workshop reports, 
follow up on identified actions, and administer the costs if needed;  
(v)  assist  the  project  officer  in  handling  the  project’s  administrative  requirements, 
including by liaising with the country team, and in facilitating liquidation of funds in 
accordance with ADB procedures; and 
(vi)  perform other related tasks as may be assigned. 
B.  Consultants for the Civil Registration and Vital Statistics Component 
3.  International  civil  registration  and  vital  statistics  consultant  (3  person-months, 
intermittent).The international consultant should have a strong background in the area of civil 
registration and vital statistics (CRVS) systems and possess a very good knowledge of the 
various aspects of the functioning of a CRVS system, methods of registering vital events and 
vital statistics (including cause of death and International Classification of Diseases version 10 
coding) and experience in working with developing countries in improving CRVS systems. 
Under the supervision of the ADB project officer, the consultant will work closely with the other 
development partners and with the national consultants and the country teams. The consultant 
will: 
(i)  assist the project officer in implementing the CRVS component of the technical 
assistance (TA) project; 
(ii)  evaluate and review country proposals and finalize proposals to be implemented 
with ADB support; these could relate to conducting comprehensive assessments of 
country  CRVS  systems,  and  developing  strategic  action  plans  including  cost 
estimates  to  establish  functional  CRVS  systems;  improving  coordination 
mechanisms for CRVS; improving registrations and sex-disaggregated statistics for 
births, deaths, and cause of deaths; improving methods for collection of data on 
non-institutional deaths (such as verbal autopsy methods); developing innovative 
methods  for  registration  management  and  compilation  of  vital  statistics;  and 
development of staff capacity;  
(iii)  provide  technical  guidance  to  the  countries  in  implementation  of  country-level 
project activities, organize regional and country workshops (as needed), provide 
training  and  prepare  training  modules,  prepare  workshop  reports,  and  identify 
follow-up actions; 
(iv)  assist countries in establishing mechanisms for coordination of project activities 
between  stakeholders  (especially  the  national  statistics  office,  vital  registration

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
agency,  ministry  of  health,  and  related  agencies);  and  provide  advice  on 
mainstreaming CRVS in national strategies for development of statistics; 
(v)  assist the project officer in collaborating with development partners that actively 
support  countries  to  improve  CRVS  systems,  and  in  developing  the  regional 
program for improvement of CRVS systems in Asia and the Pacific initiated by the 
United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific (ESCAP); 
prepare  documents  for  regional  coordination  work,  and  comment  on  related 
documents; 
(vi)  assist the project officer in organizing country and regional workshops; prepare 
agendas, technical documents and presentations for workshops and meetings, and 
serve  as  a  resource  person;  prepare  workshop  reports,  and  identify  follow-up 
actions;  
(vii)  prepare country-level project implementation reports and a consolidated report on 
CRVS country projects, with lessons; and 
(viii)  perform other related tasks as may be assigned. 
4.  National  consultant  for  civil  registration  and  vital  statistics  (12 person-months, 
intermittent, 4 person-months per country).The national consultant should have at least 5 years 
experience with their country’s CRVS system. The national consultant in each participating 
country  will  assist  the  international  consultant (CRVS)  and  country  teams  in  implementing 
project activities at the country level. The consultant will: 
(i)  assist  international  consultant  and  country  team  in  implementing  the  CRVS 
activities in the country; 
(ii)  work with the country team in preparing the country proposal for improving the 
CRVS system and activities to be implemented with ADB support; these could 
relate to conducting comprehensive assessments of country CRVS systems and 
developing  strategic  action  plans  including  the  costs  of  establishing  functional 
CRVS  systems;  improving  coordination  mechanisms  for  CRVS;  improving 
registrations  and  sex-disaggregated  statistics  for  births,  deaths,  and  cause  of 
deaths; improving methods for collection of data on non-institutional deaths (such 
as  verbal  autopsy  methods);  developing  innovative  methods  for  registration 
management and compilation of vital statistics; and development of staff capacity;  
(iii)  work  extensively  with  the  country  team  in  facilitating  and  organizing  country 
workshops and training, and collaborating between various stakeholders (e.g., the 
national statistics office, civil registration office, and ministry of health); prepare 
workshop reports and identify follow up actions; and prepare training modules as 
needed under the guidance of the international consultant;  
(iv)  closely collaborate with local development partners in supporting the country to 
improve  CRVS  systems  under  the  regional  program  for  improvement  of  civil 
registration systems in Asia and the Pacific initiated by ESCAP;  
(v)  assist in organizing country and regional workshops and preparing agendas and 
technical documents for the workshops, and serve as a resource person when 
needed;  
(vi)  assist the project officer in handling project administrative requirements by liaising 
with the country team and in facilitating liquidation of funds per ADB procedures; 
and 
(vii)  perform other related tasks as may be assigned.

Appendix 3  13 
C.  Consultants for Project Management 
6.  National  coordination  consultant  (headquarters-based,  21  person-months, 
intermittent). The  national  consultant(s)  should have  a  strong  background  in  statistics  and 
experience in conducting household surveys and project administration. The national consultant 
must be proficient with Excel and website design tools and maintenance. Under the guidance 
and supervision of the project officer, the national consultant will: 
(i)  assist  the  project  officer  (a)  in  day-to-day  coordination  of  project  work  and 
processes  within  ADB  and  with  the  countries  and  consultants,  and  (b)  with 
consultant recruitments and contract variations; 
(ii)  assist in monitoring TA implementation progress, including outputs to be delivered 
and  submission  of  consultant  reports,  and  in  following  up  on  the  outstanding 
obligations of the countries’ counterpart agencies; 
(iii)  assist in research work for the pilot surveys and in the preparation of the country 
and methodological reports; 
(iv)  assist in preparation of presentation materials, and the organization of workshops, 
seminars and training;  
(v)  maintain  the  project  website  and  assist  with  TA  implementation  (e.g.,  budget 
management and other reporting requirements); and 
(vi)  perform other related tasks as may be assigned. 
 
7.  National  data  processing  consultant  (headquarters-based,  6  person-months, 
intermittent). The consultant should have strong experience in cleaning and validation of data 
consistency in large surveys and organizing the data for tabulation and analysis. They will 
provide  capacity  building  support  to  the  country  teams  and  to  the  project  officer  in  data 
validation and quality control through development of the requisite tools. The consultant will: 
(i)  manage and organize data collected from the pilot surveys for technical reports; 
(ii)  assist  in  review  and  validation  of  data  collected  from  pilot  surveys,  including 
through preparation of data validation tools or routines that can be used by DMCs; 
when needed, they will serve as a resource person in data review workshops; 
(iii)  provide technical support to the project team on data-related concerns, and assist 
country teams with data requirements; and 
(iv)  perform other related tasks as may be assigned.  
 
8.  Resource persons (as needed, not to exceed 10 working days per resource person). 
Individual  resource  persons,  including  those  from  collaborating  development  partners  and 
specialized institutions such as the Statistical Institute for Asia and the Pacific and the University 
of Queensland Health Information System Knowledge Hub, will be engaged to provide training, 
facilitate workshops, and provide technical support specific to project needs.
